ARTICLE.TITLE: COVID-19 update for Aug. 14: Here's the latest on coronavirus in B.C.
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Here's your daily update with everything you need to know on the novel coronavirus situation in B.C. for Aug. 14, 2020.

Here’s your daily update with everything you need to know on the novel coronavirus situation in B.C. for Aug. 14, 2020.

We’ll provide summaries of what’s going on in B.C. right here so you can get the latest news at a glance. This page will be updated regularly throughout the day, with developments added as they happen.

Check back here for more updates throughout the day.

CASE SUMMARY

As of the latest figures given on Aug. 14:

• Total number of confirmed cases: 4,358 (629 active)

• New cases since Aug. 13: 84

• Hospitalized cases: 12

• Intensive care: 4

• COVID-19 related deaths: 196

• Recovered: 3,533

• Long-term care and assisted-living homes, and acute care facilities currently affected: 9

IN-DEPTH: COVID-19: Here are all the B.C. cases of the novel coronavirus

GUIDES AND LINKS

• COVID-19: Have you been exposed? Here are all B.C. public health alerts

• COVID-19: Here’s everything you need to know about the novel coronavirus

• COVID-19: Vancouver-area events postponed or cancelled because of spreading virus

• COVID-19: What’s open and closed in Metro Vancouver due to coronavirus

• B.C. COVID-19 Symptom Self-Assessment Tool

LATEST UPDATES

3 p.m. – Health officials announce 84 new cases, no new deaths

Provincial health officials announced 84 new cases of the coronavirus Friday.

The updated numbers from Health Minister Adrian Dix and Dr Bonnie Henry, B.C.’s provincial health officer, bring total confirmed cases in British Columbia to 4,358..

11 a.m. – Ryan Reynolds responds to John Horgan’s call for help

On Friday, Ryan Reynolds, who plays the Marvel superhero Deadpool, responded to Premier John Horgan on social media, saying “Called your office. Left a message” with a funny audio message, saying he is not going to offer any medical advice but urging the province’s youth to be careful so people don’t die.

“Yeah young people in B.C. are partying, which is of course dangerous and they probably don’t know that thousands of young people are not just getting sick from coronavirus but they are also dying from it too,” said Reynolds, in the audio message.

He said B.C. is home to “some of the coolest older people on Earth,” like David Suzuki and his mom.

“I hope young people in B.C. don’t kill my mom frankly. Or David Suzuki. Or each other. Let’s not kill anyone,” said Reynolds.

On Wednesday, Horgan called on Reynolds and Seth Rogen to use their influence to help get younger people to take safety precautions against the virus.

“This is a callout to Deadpool right now. Ryan, we need your help up here. Get in touch with us, my number’s on the internet,” Horgan said. “Seth Rogen, another outstanding British Columbian. We need to communicate with people who aren’t hearing us. The two of you alone could help us in that regard.”

8:30 a.m. – B.C. government reminds renters that moratorium on evictions for non payment will be lifted

Details on the new repayment framework for renters with outstanding rent from April to August 2020 are available on the Residential Tenancy Branch website, as the moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent ends ahead of Sept. 1.

As announced on July 16, renters will be expected to pay rent in full on Sept. 1, 2020, as the moratorium on evictions for non-payment of rent will end on Aug. 18.

Renters in arrears from rent due during the specified period of March 18 to Aug. 17 will have until at least July 2021 to pay back any rent they owe, with the first repayments not starting until October at the earliest.

8 a.m. – U.S. and Canada extend border closure

The United States and Canadian officials have agreed to extend a ban on non-essential travel at land borders for another 30 days as several states struggle to contain a coronavirus outbreak.

Acting U.S. Homeland Security Department Secretary Chad Wolf confirmed the action on Twitter. Reuters reported earlier Friday the planned extension at the U.S.-Canada border.

12 a.m. – Health officials say they will crack down on large parties

B.C. Health Minister Adrian Dix warned Thursday there will be no tolerance of mass gatherings as COVID-19 cases continue to surge in British Columbia.

In particular, he pointed to private parties in public places, saying if such gatherings take place this weekend, in a banquet hall, for example, attendees should expect a visit from public health or environmental officials.

He also urged people not to organize parties at private properties with alcohol and no limits on the number of people. If you are invited to a party like this, don’t go, he said.

The B.C. government banned all gatherings of more than 50 people in March as part of a package of restrictive measures to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

LOCAL RESOURCES

Here are a number of information and landing pages for COVID-19 from various health and government agencies.

• B.C. COVID-19 Symptom Self-Assessment Tool

• Vancouver Coastal Health – Information on Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19)

• HealthLink B.C. – Coronavirus (COVID-19) information page

• B.C. Centre for Disease Control – Novel coronavirus (COVID-19)

• Government of Canada – Coronavirus disease (COVID-19): Outbreak update

• World Health Organization – Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak

–with files from The Canadian Press and Reuters
